feed.title: Combined summary - BIP proposal: Authenticated prefix trees

entry.title: Combined summary - BIP proposal: Authenticated prefix trees
entry.summary: Bitcoin developer Mark Friedenbach has proposed a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) for an authenticated prefix tree data structure. The tree is based on a binary prefix and is a hybrid PATRICIA/de la Brandais tree structure that maps bitstrings to bytestrings. It compresses long sequences of non-branching nodes into a single interior node, reducing the number of hash operations required to perform updates and validate proofs. The authenticated prefix tree is ideal for encoding key-value indices that support memory-efficient proofs and is suitable for committed validation indices, committed wallet indices, efficient document time-stamping, and secure & efficient merged mining. Two variations of hashing are used to construct the prefix tree: level-compressed hashing and proof-updatable hashing. Inclusion proofs and operational proofs are also discussed in detail, including their serialization format.The email thread also discusses UTXO hash trees and partial prefix queries. Thomas Voegtlin, creator of Electrum, has developed a Python-levelDB implementation of the UTXO hash tree, which was being tested and would be added to Electrum servers. Peter Todd suggested testing the implementation thoroughly on Electrum and getting a feel for its performance and usability before any soft-fork to make it a miner commitment. There are two tree structures being discussed: a 256-way PATRICIA trie and a bitwise, non-level-compressed trie structure.Gregory Maxwell proposed restructuring the current unspent transaction output (UTXO) index as a Merkle tree, which would enable nodes without access to the UTXO set to receive transactions or entire blocks with prefixed proofs and check the validity of the transaction with just the information available. Additionally, there is discussion about UTXO commitments, which force miners and every full node with SPV clients to store the entire UTXO set perpetually, even though it is already reasonably small at approximately 300MB. Peter Todd disagrees with UTXO commitments, suggesting Namecoin as a better alternative, and recommends adding a C++ implementation to Bitcoin Core as a bloom filter replacement.The context also includes discussions on the structure of VARCHAR(), the middle position of extradata, and the possibility of using SHA-512/256 instead of SHA-256^2. There are concerns about the performance cost of validating the structure under a zero-knowledge proof, but hash function performance is not a significant cost in the near term. PGP signatures are mentioned as a cryptographic protocol that provides end-to-end encryption for secure communication.The context further describes the need for additional BIPs that describe the use of the data structure for stateless validation and mining, UBC address index for "SPV+" operating modes, document timestamping, and merged mining. It is suggested that unless the tree itself becomes part of the protocol, its specification, test vectors, and reference implementation can live elsewhere.Overall, while the performance of raw compression function may not be a significant factor in this particular BIP, it is important to carefully consider the potential impact of other factors such as zero-knowledge proof validation costs and the use of complex applications like prefix tree compression.
